fields.headline: Eurozone crisis live: Thousands protest against Greek broadcaster's closure - as it happened
fields.body:
6.55pm BST

And finally....

After this morning's tumble, European stock markets ended the day rather calmer.

The FTSE 100 actually rose 5 points, as encouraging data on US retail sales and jobless claims eased fears over central banks cutting their stimulus packages.

After dominating the headlines, Royal Bank of Scotland was the biggest faller - down 3.2%.

Here's the closing prices (and the latest ones from Wall Street)

So what's afoot in the financial market? Here's a couple of expert views:

Julian Jessop of Capital Economics:

The markets still seem disappointed that the Bank of Japan failed to ease monetary policy further at its meeting on Tuesday in response to the recent volatility in the financial markets. But any suggestions that the Japanese central bank is cooling on the need for a substantial and prolonged easing in monetary policy are wide of the mark.

After all, it was only in April that the Bank set out a clear and aggressive strategy of doubling the monetary base within two years to lift inflation to around 2%, which was much more than most had anticipated at the time. It would be quite wrong to conclude that the Bank is backtracking on that commitment now.

.....

The reaction in emerging markets has been striking too. Only a few weeks ago, the complaint was that the spill-over of liquidity from the advanced economies threatened to destabilise markets in the developing world. Now it seems as if the one thing worse than more QE is less QE! More seriously, emerging market equities have again demonstrated how hard it is for them to decouple from developed markets, particularly during a wider sell-off. However, provided the recent slide does not turn into a rout, emerging markets with low inflation and limited foreign debt may actually welcome some renewed currency weakness.

Alastair McCaig, Market Strategist, IG

European markets were given a solid kick towards negative territory before the market open with the news that the Japanese Nikkei index had closed down another 6.35% on the day and was now off over 20% from its highs, confirming that it had moved into a bear market. With limited economic data out in the morning session to shift mentality, gloom descended on trading floors across the City.

The FTSE spent much of the morning within touching distance of the 200-day moving average and there was a palpable fear that a breach of this would lead to an even more pessimistic sentiment. Half-an-hour after the US open a calmer sense of perspective emerged as the FTSE traded 100 points above its early morning low.

Last night's out-of-hours shock that Stephen Hester, the CEO of Royal Bank of Scotland, would be stepping down by the end of the year and before the bank had managed to completely float again, ensured that not only RBS but the banking sector as a whole started the day heavily in the red. Without a prepared replacement and with confidence such a fragile commodity for the banking sector, it was no surprise that the shares were trading down over 5% from the open. With almost unbearable pressure from the government and particularly close scrutiny from the press it is not instantly obvious who will be queuing up for this not particularly well-paid FTSE 100 job.

....

Who knows what delights tomorrow will bring? Probably more market turbulence, more pressure on the Greek government over ERT, and more speculation about the future of RBS!

Until then, thanks and goodnight. GW

6.40pm BST

In something of a blunder, it appears the Greek government failed to register the domain name for its new, slimmed-down broadcaster, New Hellenic Radio Internet and Television, or NERIT.

And it's now too late. An ERT supporter has snapped up www.nerit.gr, and is using it to broadcast - wait for it - the latest signal from ERT itself, as it continues to defy closure:

6.01pm BST

General strike means transport chaos in Greece

The general strike in Greece has caused havoc at Athens airport, where air traffic controllers held a two-hour walkout.

Our correspondent Helena Smith landed there this afternoon*, and reports by email:

There is MASS CHAOS at Athens airport where all means of transport with exception of taxis has been cut by strike.

I'm standing in a queue running a mile long at taxi rank. Most are befuddled tourists who have no idea what is going on! Neither do any Greeks because of news blackout.

The timing of the Greek PM's decision to shut down ERT at the beginning of the tourist season appears to have been disastrous for Greece's biggest foreign currency earner!

* - Helena had been in London attending Amnesty's Media Awards 2013, where she was nominated for her fine work covering the crisis in Greece.

5.30pm BST

inside ERT

After a day inside the ERT headquarters in Athens, reader Kizbot reports that the workers taking part in the sit-in are keeping their morale up.

She tells me:

There are a lot of very tired, worried journalists in there. But plenty of fighting spirit.

And the support from around the world is helping keep spirits up.

.

4.55pm BST

As flagged up earlier, Greek state TV's news channel, NET, was dramatically switched on again this afternoon, thanks to the Geneva-based European Broadcasting Union.

The EBU is managing to take a feed of NET from a studio in Thessaloniki and retransmitted it back to Greek homes over a satellite link. It's another blow to the Greek government's attempt to shutter the broadcaster, although other channelr are still offline.

My colleague Lisa O'Carroll explains:

The EBU said the signal is available globally on these satellites: Hotbird 13A in Europe, APSTAR 7 in Asia and Intelsat 19 in Oceania.

adding:

Staff in Athens managed to keep a makeshift service going on the internet on Wednesday, but this too was closed down, leaving the Thessaloniki output as the last link to the Greek people.

Early on Thursday, the EBU announced it was streaming the ERT feed on its website. But the EBU was able to begin TV broadcasts for ERT on Thursday afternoon after it was discovered that the satellite time had been prepaid by the Greek organisation.

Here's Lisa's full story: Greek state TV switched back on as European broadcasters step in

4.45pm BST

ERT's press office issued a statement this afternoon, urging Greek MPs not to allow police to enter their headquarters to halt their broadcasts.

In a statement, they said:

We demand from the Greek Parliament, where the majority is against the closing down of the ERT that they:

  • order the Minister of Public Order and Citizen Protection to hold back any decision about the intervention of police forces in the area and buildings of ERT.
  • order the Minister of Finance to take back all that has been told about the protection of the property of ERT. People who work in the ERT guarantee the public property of the Greek people.

Adding that they also asked the Greek president to use his influence to prevent police being deployed.

4.23pm BST

Re my last post, ERT's service is also still reaching Chile, a listener named Eduardo kindly flags up.

Shutting down a broadcaster is harder than you might think.....

3.41pm BST

Now over to a reader in North Carolina....

The Greek government failed to prevent ERT's radio services being broadcast as far as America.

Thomas Witherspoon, a radio enthusiast in Swannanoa, North Carolina, tells me that he was able to listen to the Voice Of Greece being transmitted over shortwave radio last night, and also on Tuesday after the shutdown began.

Thomas tells me:

I captured recordings of the Voice of Greece going off the air the other night, then coming back on later. They've remained on the air since then; indeed, I recorded them well into the night last night.

And he's uploaded recordings to prove it. Here's a clip of the Voice Of Greece coming back online, late on Tuesday night, as ERT workers battled to keep its services running.

More here: Voice of Greece on shortwave throughout the night, despite ERT shut down

Updated at 3.44pm BST

3.07pm BST

My colleague Lisa O'Carroll reports that the European Broadcasting Union have found a way to get some of ERT's services broadcast into people's homes again, by satellite:

Full details to follow....

The EBU kept ERT broadcasting yesterday by installing equipment in its car park in Athens.

Updated at 3.08pm BST

2.56pm BST

Greek leaders to meet on Monday

Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras appears to be looking to defuse the political crisis sparked by his decision to shut the country's state broadcaster.

Samaras's decision to meet with his junior coalition partners, Pasok's Evangelos Venizelos and Democratic Left's Fotis Kouvelis, on Monday night is an attempt to prevent his administration being dragged deeper into crisis.

Despite thousands of people taking part in today's protest rally, and the opposition of Venizelos and Kouvelis, Samaras's government is reluctant to change course.

A senior government official told Reuters that Samaras was open to discussing their proposals and a compromise was likely, though he did not intend to back down from closing ERT and relaunching a smaller, more efficient entity.

The official said:

I believe there is scope for compromise and we will not go to new elections.

Pasok and Democratic Left welcomed the meeting, which was announced this morning, but insist that ERT should not be closed.

Venizeloz said:

The country doesn't need elections, they would be a colossal mistake, but PASOK is not afraid of them....We support a radical restructuring of ERT, but not with blacked-out screens.

2.31pm BST

Video: the ERT rally

And here's a video clip of today's rally outside ERT's HQ:

2.25pm BST

Reuters reckons that 13,000 protesters gathered outside ERT's headquarters.

Many waved flags, or held banners reading "Fire Samaras, not ERT workers!"

ERT workers formed a human chain at the building's entrance.

"Samaras can't tell us what to watch or not. This isn't about ERT or about its workers any more, it's about democracy and freedom of speech," said Thanos Lykourias, 30, an office worker, who earns 800 euros a month and lives with his mother.

2.11pm BST

Photos: Protest rally outside ERT HQ

Back in Greece, more than 10,000 people have taken part in a large rally has taken place outside the headquarters of the Hellenic Broadcasting Corp, or ERT.

With today's general strike underway, the march was a show of defiance against the government's decision to close ERT down.

Staff at the broadcaster continued the sit-in that began on Tuesday, refusing to bow to government pressure and abandon their service.

ERT was broadcasting online again today, despite the Greek ministry of finance threatening to withdraw the licence of any private Greek TV channels which broadcast its services on their frequencies.

One of our readers, Kizbot, remains inside the studios and confirms that journalists are "trying to hold it together", nearly two hours after the government suddenly announced its closure

(see 10.51am and 11.11am, for Kizbot's ealier photos)

And Theodora Oikonomides, one of our regular contacts in Greece, reports there were 'high spirits' at the rally today:

Updated at 2.40pm BST

1.36pm BST

Market update

Back in the financial markets, the picture in Europe is a little less alarming.

Shares are still down, but most indices have clawed their way back from the early selloff, sparked by the Asian rout and the news that the Japanese Nikkei has now slumped into bear market territory (a hefty 20% below May's peak).

Here's the latest prices

• FTSE 100: down 48 points at 6250, -0.8%

• German DAX, down 108 points at 8034, -1.33%

• French CAC: down 18 points at 3775, -0.5%

• Spanish IBEX, down 92 points at 8032, -1.13%

We've just had some upbeat economic news from the US – retail sales rose by 0.6% in May, and the number of people filing new claims for unemployment benefit dropped by 12,000 last week.

That has driven up the US dollar against other currencies, and means Wall Street shares aren't expected to fall as sharply when trading opens in an hour.

Oh, and Marketwatch sums up the confusing picture in Japan here:

12.38pm BST

RBS shares claw back some losses

Royal Bank of Scotland's shares have recoved some ground during the government statement on Stephen Hester's departure.

They are now down 3.8% at 313p (still the biggest faller on the FTSE 100), having taken a 6% tumble as the City have an early thumbs-down to last night's news.

Traders may be encouraged that the RBS privatisation hasn't been knocked off course by the change of CEO.

Sajid Javid reiterated several times that the government wants RBS back in private hands, helping the UK economy.

Highlights of the statement start at 11.31am.

12.25pm BST

Lucas: don't privatise RBS

Caroline Lucas, Parliament's only Green MP, asks Sajid Javid why the government is so keen to sell its stake in Royal Bank of Scotland at all.

It would be better, she says, to keep RBS in public hands and use it to drive useful projects such as housebuilding and home insulation, creating thousands of jobs.

Javid disagrees, saying:

The government has no long-term role in owning any part of the banking sector.

The session is now over.

12.19pm BST

Verbal fisticuffs between Labour's Chris Bryant and economic secretary Sajid Javid.

Bryant tells MPs that you can always tell when the government is in trouble because "the chancellor runs for cover" and sends a junior minister in to the chamber to deny everying, "in this case unconvincingly".

Bryant clearly isn't persuaded that George Osborne didn't have a role in Hester's departure.

Javid hit back, reminding MPs that Bryant spoke of "a new golden age for the City of London" during his time in government, before the financial crash struck.

Perhaps they missed Andrew Tyrie's comments a few minutes earlier (see 11.53am) about how politicians should stop harking back to the past and should focus on fixing today's problems...

Updated at 12.20pm BST

12.13pm BST

Tory MP urges RBS share giveaway

Charlie Elphicke, Conservative MP, urges the government to return RBS to the public sector as swiftly as possible -- and to give shares to the public in recognition of the taxpayer's role saving RBS.

That would mean that those who paid for it get something back for it, Elphicke says.

Sajid Javid (who's been responding to all the questions for the government), replies:

We are looking at our future plans for the state-owned banking sector. However, we feel it is prudent to wait for the report from the Commission for Banking Standards.

The idea of a share giveaway – in the style of the 1980s privatisations of various utility firms – has excited many Conservatives. But as the Observer wrote in April, people should treat cautiously....

12.06pm BST

David Ward MP says it is clear that George Osborne has sacked Stephen Hester. Is there a gagging clause preventing him from speaking out?

Sajid Javid denies that the chancellor kicked Hester out.

12.03pm BST

Conservative MP Julian Smith says RBS's staff need to be protected during the handover period until a new CEO is in place. Javid agrees, saying they have played a key role in improving RBS's balance sheet.

12.02pm BST

Hester's own MP, Sir Tony Baldry, speaks up for "his constituent", saying he did a very good job after getting a poisoned chalice from the previous government.

11.57am BST

Government warned: no knockdown sale of RBS

Pat McFadden, a Labour MP who serves on the Parliamentary Commission on Banking Standards, issues a clear warning shot to Sajid Javid and the government over RBS.

"If they're looking for a permission slip for a sale [of RBS] at a knock-down price" they will be disappointed, McFadden said.

That Committee will release its report into the sector soon - and may include recommendations for the future of RBS.

Updated at 11.57am BST

11.53am BST

Andrew Tyrie, chair of the Treasury committee, speaks next. He says Hester did "a very difficult job extremely well".

Tyrie also isn't impressed by the point scoring, saying the public just want to see RBS back on its feet and serving the UK economy.

11.52am BST

Javid responds...

Economic secretary Sajid Javid responds. He ducks Leslie's first point, saying that chancellor George Osborne isn't there because he's there instead.

He tells MPs that Osborne did not meet with Hester in the last few weeks, and had not pushed the CEO out of the door,

"This is a decision for RBS and its board," Javid insists.

On the 6% drop in RBS's share price today, Javid points out that "nearly every bank is down" as part of today's market selloff. The Nikkei also fell 6% today, he points out.

True.... but the FTSE 100 is only down 1%, and RBS is the biggest faller on the FTSE 100 by some distance.

Javid also denies that the government wants to sell RBS quickly (something that is often rumoured):

We have no target prrice for RBS. we have no fixed timetime, and that does not include the general election, he said. "We just want the best price for the taxpayer".

Javid finished with a jab at Labour, saying they "overpaid by £12bn" when they bailed out RBS.

11.45am BST

Labour: Where's Osborne?

Chris Leslie, Labour's shadow treasury minister, responds to Javid's statement -- saying it's very disappointing that George Osborne is not here to answer questions on RBS.

Leslie also asks

1) whether Hester jumped, or was pushed.

2) is any truth in speculation that Sir Philip Hampton, the RBS chairman, is also planning to leave the bank (he spoke about the need for succession planning in an interview with Bloomberg today)

3) Why is there no successor? Is Hester being shoved out of the door so that the government can sell its RBS stake before the next election

Leslie points out that today's fall in RBS's share price (down nearly 6%) has cost taxpayers around £2bn.

It's time to end the confusion of RBS's future, Leslie concludes, and handle the bank in an orderly way.

11.37am BST

Sajid Javid: we're cleaning Britain's banking sector up

Sajid Javid then explains that the government is pushing on with its reforms to the UK's banking sector.

This includes implementing the Vickers review, changing the "culture and the ethics of trhe banking industry", and pushing for more choice in the sector.

We are still mopping up the huge economic mess we inherited from the party opposite.

Now it's time to move from the rescue phase to the recovery phase at RBS, and return the bank to the private sector, he adds.

11.33am BST

Hester's payment confirmed

Sajid Javid confirms that Hester will receive a payment of £1.6m when he leaves RBS, along with various unvested shares that are worth around £4m.

Javid points out that Hester only received one annual bonus under his time at RBS. He also suggests that Hester's payoff is not the fault of the current government.

Hester will be leaving with "one third of the maximum he could have received under the contract agreed under the previous government in 2008", says Javid

11.31am BST

Stephen Hester statement begins

Over in parliament, economic secretary Sajid Javid is giving a statement on Stephen Hester's departure from Royal Bank of Scotland

Javid begins by commending Hester for the job he has done over the last five years:

When Stephen Hester took over, the bank was on the brink of collapse with a broken culture and a risk to financial stability.

Hester brought it back from the brink, says Javid.

He tells MPs that the size and complexity of RBS has been reduced, with a renewed focus on its UK customers.

Hester has made an important contribution to Britain's recovery from the financial crisis, he adds.

More to follow....

11.27am BST

Stephen Hester's memo to RBS staff:

Stephen Hester. the outgoing chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland, send a memo to staff last night. In it, he thanks them for the progress made since the bank 'nearly died' in the financial crisis.

Here's the full memo:

Dear colleague,

The Board is announcing today that it is starting the search for a new
Group Chief Executive of RBS to lead the company through privatisation
and beyond. I plan to step down by the end of this year, or earlier if
a successor is in place, and to help the company as much as I can in
the meantime.

Nothing about this decision was easy, but I can see that as we head
towards a potential privatisation, now provides a window for the
company to put in place a Chief Executive that can give fresh energy
to the challenge of leading RBS through the next phase.

I joined RBS at its lowest point. We were a company close to the point
of collapse with no clear path back to recovery. All the odds and much
of the opinion was against us, but your efforts and strengths proved
to be the biggest asset in ensuring we could recover the business for
everyone who relied on us.

Five years is a long time for anyone to serve as Chief Executive. The
endless scrutiny we all face carries a cost, but it has always been
offset for me by the warmth and support of colleagues from across the
business to carry on.

This strength of teamwork is no more evident than in the leadership
team that exists in RBS today. It is the strongest such team we could
wish for and is well placed to steer the business through the next
phase of our journey to become a really good bank.

I’ve been conscious since first taking up this role that the success
of RBS should never again be cast in the image of one person.
Companies rarely succeed or fail on the actions of individuals, but on
the skills and strength of character present in all those who work
within them.

I have believed for some time now that the recovery process revealed
strength of character in RBS that lay dormant.

In the face of significant challenge, we have proven ourselves as
determined and capable people, quietly rebuilding a company that the
nation depends on. But more than this, it is now clear to me that RBS
is a company of decent, hardworking people who care a lot about doing
the right thing for customers.

In the time I have spent with so many of you, I am always heartened
when I see the depth of belief you have in doing the best for our
customers. It may surprise our critics, but this is often matched by
goodwill on the part of the many customers I meet in all parts of our
business who truly want us to succeed.

Our future success starts and finishes with this focus on customers.
We’ve made it our purpose to serve them well, and if we truly obsess
about meeting their needs over our own, then RBS will become a really
good bank. We know this to be right, not because we think it is, but
because our customers tell us this is what they want.

RBS lost sight of why it was founded, and it nearly died as a result.
We’ve got back to a place where we can once again focus on the
customer above all else. If there is one positive legacy to take from
our past mistakes it must be that we never, ever forget why we are
here.

Leading RBS is an exceptional task, only made possible by the fact
that I work with exceptional people. Thank you for all your
commitment, support and teamwork.

Be sure to continue to serve customers well.

Yours sincerely,

Stephen

11.24am BST

Key event

Proof that Greece's economic pain continues -- the country's jobless rate rose to 27.4% in the first quarter of 2013, a new record high, up from 26% in the las three months of 2012.

It's the highest quarterly unemployment rate since this data series started in 1998.

11.11am BST

One of our regular readers, Kizbot, is there, and reports that there's something of a "festival" atmosphere. She reckons the demonstrators number into the thousands, but there's no police presence beyond a traffic cop, she tells me.

She also kindly sent me several photos:

10.16am BST

Uncertainty over US monetary policy (see 8.40am) and concern that Japan's yen was strengthening drove the rout, analysts saisd

Thailand is down 5.5%, and the Phillipines market has fallen 6%, as Fast FT flags up:

After that tumultuous session in Asia, London equity dealers have unsurprisingly been left staring at screens awash with red as markets open.

Given the boost lax monetary policy has given markets this year - especially in Europe and the US - then there's plenty more room on the downside for the sell-off to continue.

fields.standfirst: Angela Ahrendts takes home £6.8m – less than half last year's £16.9m – days after being named UK's best paid FTSE boss
fields.body:
Angela Ahrendts, the chief executive of fashion label Burberry, has seen her annual take home pay drop by £10m, only days after being named as Britain's best paid boss.

Ahrendts' £16.9m total pay package in 2012 saw her leapfrog to the top of the FTSE 100 pay league, but her 2013 pay dropped to £6.8m after she decided not to cash in as many bonus shares.

Her basic salary increased by 3.5% to £1.06m, on top of which she collected a £1.5m bonus, £256,000 cash in lieu of pension and other perks worth £439,000.

The perks include a £25,000 annual clothing allowance on top of her 80% staff discount, a car and driver and help towards her children's school fees.

Ahrendts also cashed in £3.5m of previously awarded bonus shares. Her total take home pay was significantly lower than in 2012 because last year she cashed in £11.9m of shares.

She is in line to collect £6.7m of additional bonus shares in 2015 if the company hits a string of targets. The 500,000 share options were granted to Ahrendts in 2010, but are dependent on her continued "outstanding leadership".

A Burberry spokesman said: "Under the leadership of Angela Ahrendts and her senior team, Burberry has generated exceptional returns for shareholders in a period characterised by economic turbulence. Burberry continued this growth in 2012/13, delivering another year of record revenue and profit for shareholders. Adjusted earnings per share increased 14% and the full year dividend has been raised by 16%."

fields.standfirst: Downbeat forecasts help drive wave of selling in Japan amid fears that central bank stimulus measures might be withdrawn
fields.body:
The World Bank cut its forecasts for this year, citing a deeper than expected recession in Europe and a slowdown in China and India.

Renewing fears about growth, it said the global economy was likely to grow by 2.2% this year, a downgrade from its January forecast of 2.4%.

The downbeat forecasts helped to drive a wave of selling in Japan, where the Nikkei index tumbled 6.35% amid fears that central bank stimulus measures – led by the US – might be withdrawn. The World Bank also cut its forecast for growth in 2014 to 3.1% from 3%, but maintained its prediction that global GDP would increase by 3.3% in 2015.

"While there are markers of hope in the financial sector, the slowdown in the real economy is turning out to be unusually protracted," said Kaushik Basu, senior vice-president and chief economist at the bank.

"This is reflected in the stubbornly high unemployment in industrialised nations, with unemployment in the eurozone actually rising, and in the slowing growth in emerging economies."

There were also heavy losses on European stock markets in morning trading. although the FTSE 100 recovered by mid-afternoon.

Michael Hewson, senior market analyst at CMC Markets UK, a financial spread-betting company, said: "European markets have plunged on the open in the wake of the 6.35% decline in the Nikkei overnight as investors continue to worry about the longevity of central bank stimulus measures, while another global growth downgrade from a global organisation, this time the World Bank, has prompted investors to question current stock market valuations."

The bank is now predicting the eurozone economy will shrink by 0.6% this year, compared with an earlier forecast of a 0.1% decline in GDP. The currency bloc's economy is then expected to grow by 0.9% in 2014 and 1.5% in 2015.

The World Bank highlighted slowing growth in China, as authorities there seek to rebalance the economy, and said India's annual growth had dropped below 6% for the first time in 10 years. It said there was concern that the US might begin to ease its support of the world's largest economy by withdrawing quantitative easing, or the use of central bank cash to buy up sovereign debt in the hope that financial institutions will reinvest the windfall in the wider economy.

The bank added that austerity programmes, high unemployment, and weak consumer and business confidence would continue to impede growth in higher-income countries.

It downgraded its forecasts for developing countries' GDP to 5.1% this year from an earlier forecast of 5.5%. Growth in 2014 and 2015 is expected to be 5.6% and 5.7% respectively.

webTitle: Shares in Argos and Homebase owner Home Retail Group fall sharply

fields.standfirst: Home Retail Group's profitability dips as it warns consumer spending is likely to remain subdued
fields.body:
Home Retail Group shares fell sharply after the Argos and Homebase owner said consumer spending was likely to remain subdued and profitability dipped.

Shares fell 8.3% despite Home Retail Group posting a small rise in sales in the first quarter, which was not enough to offset disappointment in falling margins at Argos and Homebase.

The group said in a trading update that a fall in margins at Argos of three-quarters of a percentage point was due to the influence of consumer electronics sales which are less profitable than some other goods.

The fall in margins at Homebase in the 13 weeks to 1 June was explained by a greater number of promotions compared with the first quarter of last year. Home Retail Group said seasonal sales at both chains had been adversely affected by the unsettled weather over the period.

Terry Duddy, chief executive of the group, said: "Whilst we expect consumer spending to remain subdued, we are on track with delivering our investment plans to drive the long-term development of both Argos and Homebase."

Total sales at Argos rose 1.2% over the quarter to £828m, while like-for-like sales increased 1.9%. Internet sales at Argos grew, accounting for 42% of total sales, up from 41% a year ago.

Growth in tablets, televisions and white goods helped to offset declines in video gaming and audio sales, as well as the weaker performance in seasonal sales.

Homebase total sales were up just 0.2% at £422m, although like-for-like sales rose 1.4%. Nick Bubb, an independent retail analyst, said the sharp fall in the share price partly reflected declines in the wider market but added the update itself was disappointing.

"They have chosen a bad day to disappoint the market, but it is also disappointed by the slowdown in online growth, and people are looking to take profits on things that are very exposed to the British consumer. It is clearly not easy out there."

webTitle: Global financial markets anxious to avoid many pitfalls of 'political risk'

fields.bodyText: When investors in the world's financial markets are in an anxious mood, such as in recent weeks, any new piece of information tends to be taken as a fresh reason to sell. Their overarching concern – and the markets' frame for almost everything else that happens – is that the US Federal Reserve may be considering "tapering" its massive quantitative easing programme, amid signs that the world's largest economy is starting to recover. It's unlikely that any change to the Fed's bond-buying plan is imminent; but the merest hint – dropped by chairman Ben Bernanke on 22 May – that the flood of cheap money that has supercharged markets could slow to a trickle has been enough to rock confidence. Against that background, investors were already in a mood to pull funds out of riskier emerging markets, which won't look such a great bet without cheap money to gamble with. Elsewhere the turmoil in Greece, with the abrupt shutdown of the state broadcaster prompting renewed alarm about the stability of the governing coalition, reopened familiar fears about the euro crisis. Meanwhile, the violent crackdown on protests in Turkey – formerly seen as a paragon of stability – has given added impetus to investors' desire to run a mile from what is politely called "political risk". Another set of markets rocked in recent days has been those such as Australia, where the economy is heavily dependent on exports to China. There are increasing signs that China is slowing as its growth model changes, and there are also alarming reports about the fragile state of the financial sector. A sharp downturn in China would rock a whole range of economies that rode out the Great Recession on the back of rampant Chinese demand. The final factor alarming investors is that the gloss appears to be coming off Abenomics – the Japanese government's plan for radically rebooting the country's economy. Many commentators have been disappointed by the so-called "third arrow" of Abe's policies. In addition to fiscal stimulus and "shock and awe" quantitative easing, Abe was expected to use the breathing space created by QE to implement a range of structural reforms to kickstart stodgy businesses and rebuild the tax system. But so far there has been scant detail. At the same time, the yen has been rising sharply – exactly the opposite effect to the one the Japanese authorities had hoped for – choking off the recovery by smashing demand for Japan's exports. The markets' response to the initial announcement from the Bank of Japan that it planned to double the size of the country's monetary base was so drastic that even if the policy had been unqualified success, the Nikkei would probably have looked overvalued. But the niggling doubts about the policy's effectiveness are unlikely to be assuaged in the short term. It was clear for some months that markets had become overvalued, getting ahead of the pace of recovery in major economies, and disregarding the continuing risk of turmoil in the eurozone and across a range of emerging markets. It is still not clear whether the selloff in recent days marks the end of the bull run artificially engineered by the world's central banks. But investors everywhere are bracing themselves for a long, volatile summer.

webTitle: British Gas owner Centrica agrees £160m Bowland shale fracking deal

fields.standfirst: Entrance of big name into British shale sector could be catalyst for fracking industry
fields.body:
The British Gas owner, Centrica, will invest up to £160m in shale gas exploration and development in the north-west after agreeing a deal with Britain's leading fracking company.

Centrica has bought a 25% stake in the Bowland exploration licence in Lancashire from Cuadrilla Resources and AJ Lucas for £40m. It will pay a further £60m in exploration and appraisal costs.

An additional £60m will be payable if Centrica subsequently decides to move into a development phase.

The entrance of such a big name into the British shale sector could be a catalyst for an industry that has until now been made up of relatively small companies. It follows speculation about a possible deal last week, and comes just months after the company played down prospects for shale gas.

"With North Sea gas reserves declining and the UK becoming more dependent on imported gas supplies, it is important that we look for opportunities to develop domestic gas resources, to provide affordable sources of gas to our customers, and to deliver broader economic benefits to the UK," said Mark Hanafin, managing director of Centrica's international upstream business on Thursday.

"The government's clear commitment to developing the UK's shale gas industry is creating the right environment for companies to invest and to deliver those benefits."

The Bowland licence is operated by Cuadrilla, with three exploration wells drilled to date. Centrica said data obtained from the drilling process had confirmed the presence of natural gas.

It added initial work suggested there could be 200 trillion cubic feet of gas in place relating to the Bowland shale licence, although it cautioned "further drilling will be required to establish whether the discovery is commercial".

A report from the Institute of Directors in May estimated that natural gas from shale could reduce the amount of gas the UK has to import in 2030 from 76% to 37%.

UK-wide investment could reach £3.7bn a year, supporting 74,000 jobs across the industry and its supply chain, the report said.

Centrica insisted in January that shale gas was not "the game-changer we've seen in North America" and played down speculation that it might start drilling.

webTitle: Mulberry profits fall for first time in four years as Asian customers cut back

fields.standfirst: Luxury brand's 28% fall in full-year pre-tax profits comes days after creative director Emma Hill announced intention to quit
fields.body:
Mulberry's profits have fallen for the first time in four years as Asian suppliers cut back on wholesale orders from the luxury goods maker and tourists rein in spending.

The 28% fall in full-year pre-tax profits to £26m comes days after the creative director Emma Hill said she wanted to quit after six years at the company. She had been responsible for turning the brand from a conservative, niche label into a global brand favoured by celebrities from Kate Moss to Lana Del Rey. Sales were down 2% from £169m to £165m in the year to end of March, mainly due to weak Asian demand and wholesale orders falling.

Mulberry's chief executive, Bruno Guillon, said he wants to turn the brand from an affordable luxury into a more high-end operation targeting the affluent Chinese market in particular. He said: "After three years of rapid growth, we have had a year of consolidation during which we have laid the foundations for the transition of Mulberry from a UK success story into a global luxury brand. Greater visibility in Asia will allow us to benefit from tourist traffic in Europe and the US at the same time as growing our business locally."

Prices have risen 12% in the last year for the business, which sells its famous Alexa bag, named after TV presenter Alexa Chung, for up to £2,500. Retail sales rose 6% on a like-for-like basis to £107.2m thanks to the price rise, with customers in Europe and the UK accounting for 80% of business. Guillon, who joined last year, opened a second factory in Somerset this month and said he plans to open between 15 and 20 more stores worldwide.

However, it has been a difficult time for the boss ,who joined from French brand Hermès. He has been forced to issue three profit warnings over the past year, blaming the poor wholesale market and saying not enough tourists were buying the more expensive ranges at Mulberry's London stores over the Christmas period.

On Thursday he said several wholesale accounts across Europe had been closed as the downturn continues to bite. The share price has fallen heavily in the last year, after hitting an all-time high of £24.72 in May 2012. But the shares now sit at 934p, having slipped a further 1.5% on Thursday morning.

The company revealed on Monday that creative director Hill, who was awarded a CBE for services to fashion last year, wanted to leave. Industry sources have suggested she is unhappy with the boardroom strategy.

webTitle: WH Smith sales fall as high street slump hits home

fields.standfirst: High street sales down 8% in chief executive Kate Swann's final trading update before she leaves at end of month
fields.body:
A weak performance at WH Smith's high street stores has dragged down its sales over the last three months, the company reported on Thursday.

Total group sales fell 5% in the 14 weeks to 8 June, while like-for-like sales, stripping out the impact of additional floor space, were down 6% compared with the same period last year.

WH Smith said it was cautious but confident in the trading update. "The economic environment remains uncertain and whilst we continue to be cautious about consumer spending, we remain confident in the outcome for the full year."

Shares in the company fell almost 1% in early trading, to 724p.

High street sales fell more sharply than those within its travel business, which covers airports, railway stations, hospitals and motorway service stations.

Total high street sales were down 8% and like-for-like sales down 7% over the period. The company said this partly reflected a strong publishing schedule last year. Total travel sales were flat and like-for-like sales were down 4%.

The trading update comes as chief executive Kate Swann prepares to leave at the end of the month after nine years in the job.

She joined in 2003 when the retailer was being hit by competition both from the supermarkets and online, and has been credited with turning the business around.

She embarked on an extensive cost-cutting programme, closed WH Smith's final-salary pension scheme, abandoned the sale of entertainment products to focus on newspapers, magazines and stationery, and created a vast travel business.

Swann will be replaced by Steve Clarke, managing director of WH Smith's high street business.

The company said gross margins were up and cost savings within its high street business had been delivered in line with plans.

"We confirm that our financial position is in line with market expectations and our balance sheet remains strong. We continue to generate high levels of cash from our operations," the company said.

It confirmed it had purchased 5m shares as of 12 June, and returned to shareholders £34m of the £50m share buyback announced in August 2012.

webTitle: Workplace greying as companies turn to older employees

fields.standfirst: For first time there are now more than 1 million workers in UK aged over 65
fields.body:
The number of workers in Britain aged over 65 has risen above 1 million for the first time as firms increasingly prefer older employees to younger staff.

Latest jobless figures from the Office for National Statistics highlighted the "greying" of the workplace amid signs that growth in early 2013 is starting to have an effect on jobs.

Data released on Wednesday shows that unemployment fell by 5,000 to 2.51 million in the three months ending in April.

Employment rose by 24,000 during the quarter, beating the City's expectations of a small fall in the number of people in work. The ONS said there were now 29.76 million people in employment, up 432,000 on a year ago.

Of these, 1,030,000 were over 65, up by 38,000 on the quarter and by 96,000 on the February-to-April period of 2012.

Younger people had a tougher time breaking into the jobs market. The number of 16-24-year-olds in employment fell by 4,000 to 3.68 million in the three months to April.

Jim Hillage, director of research at the Institute for Employment Studies, said the rise in employment for the over-65s was significant. "While this reflects a welcome willingness among employers to recruit and retain experienced people, it may also reflect the need that some older people have to top up inadequate pension arrangements."

Jobs continue to be shed from the public sector, with employment down by 22,000 in the latest period for which figures are available, the three months to March 2013. But an expanding private sector created 46,000 additional jobs in the same period.

The ONS said the UK's jobless rate remained unchanged between the latest quarters at 7.8%, but that it was down 0.4 points on the previous year. The government's alternative measure of unemployment – the number of people claiming Jobseeker's Allowance – fell by 8,600 to 1.51 million in May, the ONS said.

Higher bonus payments led to an increase in the rate of growth of average earnings. Although still running below the current 2.7% inflation rate, earnings were 1.3% higher between February and April than a year earlier. That compared with a 0.6% increase in the three months ending in March.

The official data came in the wake of a report from the Institute for Fiscal Studies showing a 6% drop in real wages since the start of the recession – the biggest five-year drop since modern records began.

The jobs figures added to City speculation that the economy will grow by around 0.5-0.6% in the second quarter of 2013, following 0.3% expansion in the first three months of the year.

Mark Hoban, employment minister, said: "It's a credit to the growth of British businesses up and down the country that we now have a record number of people employed in the private sector.

"With the number of people in work increasing, and unemployment down, these are welcome figures. The fact that youth unemployment is also down is a positive sign. But we are not complacent. Through schemes like the Work Programme and the Youth Contract we will continue to help people find the jobs they need so they can realise their aspiration of looking after themselves and their families and help the country compete in the global race."

Ian Brinkley, director of the Work Foundation, said: "The labour market figures released this morning give a mixed picture. Overall, employment is still holding up, especially in the private sector. But long term unemployment is still rising. Nearly 900,000 people have been out of work for more than a year, and nearly 460,000 out of work for more than two years.

"The coalition needs to set out clearly in this month's spending review how it intends to reverse this trend, which is damaging the job prospects of individuals and our long-term economic success."

webTitle: EasyJet deal at Stansted could halt decline

fields.standfirst: Airline may double its passengers at the Essex airport over the next five years
fields.body:
The new owner of London Stansted has announced a deal with easyJet that could see the airline double its passengers at the Essex airport over the next five years.

MAG, which bought Stansted from Heathrow in February for £1.5bn, said the "long-term growth framework" agreed with the airline was a positive first step as it tries to turn around the nosedive in passenger numbers over the past few years.

Easyjet flies eight aircraft on up to 27 routes out of London Stansted, making it roughly half the size of its Luton operation and a sixth of that at Gatwick. However, the deal will be seen as significant as a potential vote of confidence in the airport, which has long been lambasted – most notably by Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary – for perceived high charges.

The easyJet deal will mean progressively lower charges as passenger volume rises but is understood to be only one option for the airline as it considers where to deploy its aircraft in the coming years. The airline struck similar agreements at Edinburgh and Gatwick airports after competition authorities forced the company then known as BAA to sell most of its airports bar Heathrow.

Charlie Cornish, chief executive of MAG, said: "We are delighted that easyJet has chosen Stansted. We're working hard with existing and prospective airlines to drive passenger growth at Stansted so the announcement by easyJet on the new framework for growth is a positive first step.

"The quality of our offer is compelling and we strongly believe that London Stansted has a key role to play in any debate on south-east capacity and today's positive announcement by easyJet confirms that."
